nodes.text: High public and external debt levels have systematic adverse macroeconomic effects on growth and, in some contexts, on inflation

Dataset and empirical approach: new multi-country historical dataset covering 44 countries, about 200 years, over 3,700 annual observations of central government debt, plus more recent external debt series
Primary result for central government debt: when public debt exceeds roughly 90 percent of GDP median GDP growth is about one percentage point lower and mean growth is several percentage points lower
Cross-country pattern for growth: the negative growth association at very high public debt is similar for advanced economies and emerging markets

Inflation differences: no systematic relationship between high public debt and inflation for advanced economies as a group, whereas emerging markets show substantially higher inflation at high public debt levels
Evidence on 2007-2009: public debt rose sharply since 2007, with crisis countries' average debt levels up about 75 percent and even non-crisis countries up about 20 percent between 2007 and 2009
Data scope limitation: external debt series for advanced countries begin only around 2000, limiting threshold analysis for advanced-country external debt
Mechanism and interpretation: nonlinear 'debt intolerance' response plausibly operates via rising market interest rates that force fiscal adjustment, hurting growth
Mechanism for emerging markets' inflation: fiscal dominance and reliance on external borrowing plausibly explain why higher public/external debt coincides with higher inflation
Policy implication: reliance on short-term borrowing increases vulnerability to crises of confidence and sudden interest rate spikes, so debt management matters for policy

External debt thresholds for emerging markets: gross external debt above 60 percent of GDP associated with about 2 percentage point lower annual growth; above 90 percent associated with growth roughly halved or outright declines and higher inflation
Data limitation on private domestic debt: reliable long-run cross-country series on private domestic debt are scarce, giving a partial view when focusing on public and external debt
Private sector deleveraging after financial crises: private debt contracts sharply after crises, which exacerbates downturns and may damp medium-term growth

Historical summary conclusion: across 44 countries and up to two centuries, high debt/GDP (90 percent and above) is robustly associated with notably lower growth outcomes and countries rarely 'grow' out of such debt levels
